content.text: Bash df Command - File System Disk Space Usage
Using the df Command
The df command is used to report file system disk space usage.
content.html: The df command is used to report file system disk space usage.

content.text: It's a useful tool for checking available storage on your system.
content.html: It's a useful tool for checking available storage on your system.

content.text: All examples below use a hypothetical output for demonstration:
content.html: All examples below use a hypothetical output for demonstration:

content.code:
Filesystem     1K-blocks    Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1
20480000

1024000

19456000

5
% /
tmpfs
4096000

0

4096000

0
% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1
10240000

512000

9728000

5
% /mnt/data
content.code_html:
Filesystem     1K-blocks    Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1       20480000 1024000  19456000   5% /
tmpfs            4096000       0   4096000   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1       10240000  512000   9728000   5% /mnt/data

content.text: Understanding the Output
The df command output consists of several columns, each representing different aspects of the file system's disk usage:
content.html: The df command output consists of several columns, each representing different aspects of the file system's disk usage:

content.text: Basic Usage
To display disk space usage, use df :
content.html: To display disk space usage, use df:

content.code:
df

Filesystem     1K-blocks    Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1       20480000 1024000  19456000   5% /
tmpfs            4096000       0   4096000   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1       10240000  512000   9728000   5% /mnt/data
content.code_html:
df
Filesystem     1K-blocks    Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1       20480000 1024000  19456000   5% /
tmpfs            4096000       0   4096000   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1       10240000  512000   9728000   5% /mnt/data

content.text: Options
The df command has options to change how it works:
content.html: The df command has options to change how it works:

content.text: Show Sizes in Human-Readable Format
The -h option allows you to show sizes in human-readable format.
content.html: The -h option allows you to show sizes in human-readable format.

content.code:
df
-h
Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1        20G  1.0G   19G   5% /
tmpfs           4.0G     0  4.0G   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1        10G  500M  9.5G   5% /mnt/data
content.code_html:
df -h
Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1        20G  1.0G   19G   5% /
tmpfs           4.0G     0  4.0G   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1        10G  500M  9.5G   5% /mnt/data

content.text: Show All File Systems
The -a option allows you to show all file systems, even empty ones.
content.html: The -a option allows you to show all file systems, even empty ones.

content.code:
df
-a
Filesystem     1K-blocks    Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1       20480000 1024000  19456000   5% /
tmpfs            4096000       0   4096000   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1       10240000  512000   9728000   5% /mnt/data
none                   0       0         0    - /proc/sys/fs/binfmt_misc
content.code_html:
df -a
Filesystem     1K-blocks    Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1       20480000 1024000  19456000   5% /
tmpfs            4096000       0   4096000   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1       10240000  512000   9728000   5% /mnt/data
none                   0       0         0    - /proc/sys/fs/binfmt_misc

content.text: Show File System Type
The -T option allows you to show the type of file system.
content.html: The -T option allows you to show the type of file system.

content.code:
df
-T
Filesystem     Type     1K-blocks    Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1      ext4      20480000 1024000  19456000   5% /
tmpfs          tmpfs      4096000       0   4096000   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1      ext4      10240000  512000   9728000   5% /mnt/data
content.code_html:
df -T
Filesystem     Type     1K-blocks    Used Available Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1      ext4      20480000 1024000  19456000   5% /
tmpfs          tmpfs      4096000       0   4096000   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1      ext4      10240000  512000   9728000   5% /mnt/data

content.text: File System Type: This indicates the format and structure used to store and organize data on a disk.
content.html: File System Type: This indicates the format and structure used to store and organize data on a disk.

content.text: Common file system types include ext4 , ntfs , and vfat .
content.html: Common file system types include ext4, ntfs, and vfat.

content.text: Each type has its own features, limitations, and compatibility with operating systems.
content.html: Each type has its own features, limitations, and compatibility with operating systems.

content.text: Show Inode Usage
The -i option allows you to show inode usage.
content.html: The -i option allows you to show inode usage.

content.code:
df
-i
Filesystem     Inodes IUsed IFree IUse% Mounted on
/dev/sda1     1310720  2560 1308160    1% /
tmpfs         1048576     1 1048575    1% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1      655360   100  655260    1% /mnt/data
content.code_html:
df -i
Filesystem     Inodes IUsed IFree IUse% Mounted on
/dev/sda1     1310720  2560 1308160    1% /
tmpfs         1048576     1 1048575    1% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1      655360   100  655260    1% /mnt/data

content.text: Inodes: Inodes are data structures used by many file systems to store information about files and directories, such as their size, owner, permissions, and timestamps.
content.html: Inodes: Inodes are data structures used by many file systems to store information about files and directories, such as their size, owner, permissions, and timestamps.

content.text: Each file or directory has a unique inode. The df -i command shows inode usage, which can be important for systems with many small files.
content.html: Each file or directory has a unique inode. The df -i command shows inode usage, which can be important for systems with many small files.

content.text: Use POSIX Output Format
The -P option allows you to use the POSIX output format.
content.html: The -P option allows you to use the POSIX output format.

content.code:
df
-P
Filesystem     1024-blocks    Used Available Capacity Mounted on
/dev/sda1       20480000 1024000  19456000       5% /
tmpfs            4096000       0   4096000       0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1       10240000  512000   9728000       5% /mnt/data
content.code_html:
df -P
Filesystem     1024-blocks    Used Available Capacity Mounted on
/dev/sda1       20480000 1024000  19456000       5% /
tmpfs            4096000       0   4096000       0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1       10240000  512000   9728000       5% /mnt/data

content.text: POSIX: POSIX (Portable Operating System Interface) is a set of standards specified by the IEEE for maintaining compatibility between operating systems.
content.html: POSIX: POSIX (Portable Operating System Interface) is a set of standards specified by the IEEE for maintaining compatibility between operating systems.

content.text: The df -P option provides output in a POSIX-compliant format, ensuring consistency across different environments and systems.
content.html: The df -P option provides output in a POSIX-compliant format, ensuring consistency across different environments and systems.

content.text: Combining Options
Options can be combined to provide more detailed output.
content.html: Options can be combined to provide more detailed output.

content.text: For example, df -hT shows sizes in human-readable format along with the file system type.
content.html: For example, df -hT shows sizes in human-readable format along with the file system type.

content.code:
df
-hT
Filesystem     Type     Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1      ext4      20G  1.0G   19G   5% /
tmpfs          tmpfs    4.0G     0  4.0G   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1      ext4      10G  500M  9.5G   5% /mnt/data
content.code_html:
df -hT
Filesystem     Type     Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1      ext4      20G  1.0G   19G   5% /
tmpfs          tmpfs    4.0G     0  4.0G   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1      ext4      10G  500M  9.5G   5% /mnt/data
